attachment.name: Photos from The Straits Times's post

media.alt: Pearls Centre has to make way for underground tunnelling works for the $18 billion Thomson Line, Singapore’s sixth MRT line, spanning 30km and 22 stations. By the end of Tuesday (March 1), the Singapore Land Authority had taken over and hoarding was put up around the building in Chinatown. ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI

Lorry driver Liu Hai Jun (in black shirt), 36, helping to move a resident's furniture at Pearls Centre on Monday. Residents had to hand their apartments over to the centre’s management that day. ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI
Meanwhile, shops on the fourth floor of the centre were all shut. ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI

Mobile phone ads are seen on the building’s lift doors. There were a total of 199 commercial units in the centre’s four-storey mall and shops included travel agencies, beauty parlours, traditional Chinese medicine shops and eateries. ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI

Posters pinned on notice boards show images of KTV hostesses and movie timings for Yangtze Cinema. The cinema began to screen R21 movies in 1995 due to the slowdown in the local movie industry and the rise of modern cineplexes. ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI

The escalator leading to Yangtze Cinema’s two halls. The cinema used to have four halls. In 2011, when its popularity dipped, two halls were converted into a nightclub with a bar, a stage and 24 private KTV rooms.ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI

One of the halls of Yangtze Cinema, which opened in 1977 and started business showing mainly Hong Kong martial arts films. The cinema later became known for screening R21 movies from Europe, Japan and South Korea. ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI

Film reels stored inside the projector room of Yangtze Cinema. The two halls at the cinema in Pearls Centre screened their last R21 movies at 5pm on Monday. The acquisition of the centre was announced by the Government in 2012. ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI

A fireproof sliding door at the carpark of Pearls Centre. The 23-storey strata-titled building began its 99-year lease in 1969. Besides the 199 commercial units in the mall, it has 44 one-, two- and three-room residential units on 11 floors. ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI

message: Pearls Centre in Chinatown has to go due to underground tunnelling works for the $18 billion Thomson Line. ST photojournalist Lim Yaohui chronicles the building's last days. http://str.sg/ZyaR

attachment.name: Mum admits abusing 4-year-old who later died
attachment.caption: STRAITSTIMES.COM
attachment.description: Frustrated that his learning ability did not match her expectations, a mother stepped on the ribs of her then two-year-old son, in the first of several instances ...

media.alt: Frustrated that his learning ability did not match her expectations, a mother stepped on the ribs of her then two-year-old son, in the first of several instances ...

message:
She had twisted his arm and stepped on his ribs when he was 2. He was brought to hospital and found to have fractures. The abuse continued and turned fatal two years later.

In 2014, Noraidah Mohd Yussof pushed her 4-year-old son to the floor when he could not recite numbers 11 to 18. He got up and continued reciting as he followed her around the flat. She continued to assault him - pushing him to the floor and stepping on his knees. Eventually, she held him by the neck and lifted him off the ground. He stopped moving shortly after.

attachment.name: Shanghai's allure fading for migrants
attachment.caption: straitstimes.com
attachment.description: After living in Shanghai for nine years, Mr Teng Yiye, 38, and his family moved to a small town in neighbouring Jiangsu province in late 2014. It takes Mr Teng about an hour to drive to Shanghai to attend meetings for his interior design business, but he believes he made the right decision to leave…

media.alt: After living in Shanghai for nine years, Mr Teng Yiye, 38, and his family moved to a small town in neighbouring Jiangsu province in late 2014. It takes Mr Teng about an hour to drive to Shanghai to attend meetings for his interior design business, but he believes he made the right decision to leave…

message: For decades, the financial hub attracted migrants from all over China. But last year, for the first time in 15 years, Shanghai saw a dip in the number of migrants. This in turn led to a decline in its population - the first decrease since China's opening up and reform in the late 1970s. http://bit.ly/21MNQaV

attachment.name: F1 treats for ST Run participants
attachment.caption: straitstimes.com
attachment.description: The excitement of Formula One will be coming to The Straits Times Run in the City. The Singapore Grand Prix has partnered the ST Run to give runners a unique race-day experience during the event on May 22.. Read more at straitstimes.com.

media.alt: The excitement of Formula One will be coming to The Straits Times Run in the City. The Singapore Grand Prix has partnered the ST Run to give runners a unique race-day experience during the event on May 22.. Read more at straitstimes.com.

message:
The Formula One Singapore Grand is teaming up with The ST Run in the City to offer participants a unique experience. Early-bird sign ups can stand to win over $12,000 worth of prizes.

Right from the flag-off and through to the post-race carnival, runners will find aspects of F1 woven into the ST Run. 

From starting on the same starting grid as the F1 speed machines, to the top runners being greeted at the finish line by a chequered flag, the runners will be forgiven if they imagine themselves to be a Ferrari or a Red Bull.

Find out more: www.straitstimes.com/singapore/f1-treats-for-st-run-participants

Register for the May 22 run at: www.straitstimesrun.com

attachment.name: Computer that beat Go champion has many applications, says maker
attachment.caption: STRAITSTIMES.COM
attachment.description: A little chalkboard sits on the reception desk of DeepMind's office in London's gentrified King's Cross. On it is scrawled: AlphaGo - 4, Lee Sedol - 1. Nearby in the lobby, a big-screen TV is flashing the words: Welcome back AlphaGo Team!. Read more at straitstimes.com.

media.alt: A little chalkboard sits on the reception desk of DeepMind's office in London's gentrified King's Cross. On it is scrawled: AlphaGo - 4, Lee Sedol - 1. Nearby in the lobby, a big-screen TV is flashing the words: Welcome back AlphaGo Team!. Read more at straitstimes.com.

message:
"When I was a kid, I'd always think of Singapore as this magical futuristic world. And I think it's still a bit like that today. I'd like to go back there more often." So says Demis Hassabis, co-founder of the company behind super computer program AlphaGo. 

His mum is Singaporean and up till the age of 10, he spent his summers here.
